steps.title: Know that Bumping a Lock is the best method.
steps.content: Know that Bumping a Lock is the best method.

steps.title: Procure or make a bump key.
steps.content: Procure or make a bump key . Procuring a bump key involves asking for a locksmith to make a 999 key (where all the valleys are cut to the maximum depth.) [1] X Research source Asking for a 999 key may cast you under suspicion, so be careful. Get your triangular file to go with it.

steps.title: Follow the directions on the wikiHow how article on bumping a lock.
steps.content: Follow the directions on the wikiHow how article on bumping a lock.

steps.title: Note there are bump proof locks out there.
steps.content: Note there are bump proof locks out there. It is unlikely that you have one.

steps.title: Know that most of these methods will not work.
steps.content: Know that most of these methods will not work. They will only work if you have a cheaper lock, or a very respectable tool set.

steps.title: Try a large hammer.
steps.content: Try a large hammer. Sometimes, a good jolt will knock the lock free. This won't work on all locks, but you may have some fun. [2] X Research source If the lock is on a wooden door, the odds are you will break the door before the lock.

steps.title: Try an electric drill.
steps.content: Try an electric drill. A drill should go right through the center of the lock where the mechanism is. This won't work on most master locks, and will likely disable the lock so it cannot even be opened with the proper key.

steps.title: Try a power saw.
steps.content: Try a power saw. The right power saw cuts through the lock itself. The New York city fire department uses saws with an aluminum oxide blade. It is effective when you can access the lock with it. Wear eye protection and cut through the body of the lock (not the shackle.) [3] X Research source

steps.title: Try bolt cutters.
steps.content: Try bolt cutters. You can use this tool on the shackle or on an attached cable. If the lock is attached to a cable, you may have better luck cutting the cable than the lock. If you want to try to cut open the lock itself, cut the shackle. This will not work on most master locks, as they are made of case hardened steel.

steps.title: Try using a pair of Channellock pliers.
steps.content: Try using a pair of Channellock pliers. This only works if there is enough space to fit the pliers in. Similarly, for huge padlocks, a car jack may work to separate the lock. Naturally, these methods only work if there is enough space.

steps.title: Do not use a gun.
steps.content: Do not use a gun. You can actually open the lock with a high powered rifle, but you may be sprayed with metal fragments or ricocheting pieces. This was proven by the Mythbusters. The Mythbusters tried a 9mm, a 357 magnum, a shotgun, and a M1 Garand rifle. The handguns did not work at all. The shotgun loosened it up It is not safe to do this. Ricochets could kill you or someone else. The high-powered rifle created shrapnel. Don't try it.

steps.title: Buy a Shim.
steps.content: Buy a Shim. They are available at lock stores or online. A shim is a small and thin piece of metal that can slide between the gaps of a lock.

steps.title: You can also try making a shim with an aluminum can; this will be free.
steps.content: You can also try making a shim with an aluminum can; this will be free. Slide the shim into the locking side of your Master lock and move the shim back and forth. Sometimes, your lock will pop open! You need to be pretty mechanical to try this, but if you do it you will have your lock intact. It may not work if you have a high-quality lock with strong springs, so better for a cheaper lock. 70% of wikihowians who tried making a shim told us it worked.

steps.title: Crack the combination
steps.content: Crack the combination using some experiments and math. You need manual dexterity to feel the sticking point of the locks. 55% of wikihowians who tried this reported it worked.

steps.title: If your lock has a key, you can try picking it.
steps.content: If your lock has a key, you can try picking it. Picking a lock takes practice, and is not recommended if you are in a hurry (like, if you have been locked out.) You also need the correct tools. You want a torsion wrench and pick. The best tools to improvise from would be a filed down allen wrench or very thin flat head screwdriver.

steps.title: Download a "Lost Combination Form" from Master Lock.
steps.content: Download a "Lost Combination Form" from Master Lock. This can be found here on the masterlock website here. Wait to fill out your form until you meet with a notary public.

steps.title: Take your form to a notary public, and ask to have the form notarized.
steps.content: Take your form to a notary public , and ask to have the form notarized. You can usually find a notary at your local bank. Fill out the form in the presence of the notary public. Have the appropriate ID that you'll need to confirm your identity. Pay the notary's fee. Master Lock won't reimburse you for the charges.

steps.title: Photocopy your lock's serial number onto a piece of paper.
steps.content: Photocopy your lock's serial number onto a piece of paper. The photocopy should show that your lock isn't attached to anything. Then, hand write the serial number beneath the picture of the lock.

steps.title: Mail your notarized form and photocopy to:
steps.content: Mail your notarized form and photocopy to: Master Lock Warehouse 1600 W. La Quinta Rd. Suite/WHSE #1 Nogales, AZ 85621
